dc:description: The SMS gene has been associated with syndromic X-linked intellectual disability Snyder type in (at least) 10 probands in 8 publications. At least 9 unique variants (missense, out-of-frame-splice) have been reported in humans, and variants in this gene segregated with disease in at least 12 additional family members. SMS was first associated with this disease in humans in 2003 (Cason et al.). The mechanism for disease is thought to be that variants that destabilize the dimer cause loss of the SMS protein, leading a dearth of sperimine which is an essential developmental polyamine. This has been demonstrated by animal models, expression studies, functional alteration studies, and analysis of the crystal structure of SMS (Wu 2008, Zhange 2013, Wang 2011, Peng 2016, Zhang 2011, Li 2018, Pegg 2009, Pegg 2011). In summary, SMS is definitively associated with syndromic X-linked intellectual disability Snyder type. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

*SMS* was first reported in relation to syndromic X-linked intellectual disability Snyder type in 2003 (Cason et al., PMID: 14508504). Nine unique variants (missense, out-of-frame-splice) that have been reported in 10 probands in 9 publications (PMIDs: 14508504, 18550699, 19206178, 22612257, 23696453, 25888122, 26174906, 26350204, 26761001) are included in this curation. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in at least 12 additional family members. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function. Variants that destabilize the dimer cause loss of the SMS protein, leading to a dearth of sperimine, which is an essential developmental polyamine. This has been demonstrated by animal models, functional alteration studies, and analysis of the crystal structure of SMS.

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *SMS* and syndromic X-linked intellectual disability Snyder type. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on May 16, 2018 (SOP Version 5).

evidence.dc:description: Yes, there are enough obligate carriers (5) to reach the required number of individuals to count the LOD score. this is still a candidate LOD.

member.rdfs:label: III-2
member.detectionMethod: Used linkage analysis to identify the DXS1226 gene and found that SMS was the best candidate so they only performed RT-PCR on the SMS gene. Used reference sequence NM_004595
member.phenotypeFreeText: Snyder robinson phenotype with myclonic-like seizures, profound mental retardation, absent speech, generalized tonic-clonic and absence seizures, unable to stand alone or walk, facial dysmorphism noted with mild hypertelorism, exophthalmia, short fphiltrum, thickened lower lip, slight high arched palate, mandivular prognathism, ears with prominent antihelicies

Signiifcant reduction in spermine levels

member.rdfs:label: V-2
member.detectionMethod: RT PCR of the SMS gene in family members with and without the disease. DHPLC analysis detected an altered migration of exon 4 in K8145.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Snyder-Robinson syndropme: mild to moderate mental retardation, hypotonia, cerebellar circuitry dysfunction, facial asymmetry, thin habitus, osteoporosis, kyphoscoliosis, decreased activity of SMS, correspondingly low levels of intracellular spermine in lymphocytes and fibroblasts, elevated spermidine/spermine ratio.

member.phenotypeFreeText: Snyder Robinson Syndrome, osteoporosis, intellectual disability, dysmorphic facies, developmental delay, progressive loss of motor skills and vocalization due to a perinatal intraventricular hemorrhage, cystic encephalomalacia, inability to walk (proband). The proband's brother had developmental delay, hypotonia, regression of milestones, but no hemorrhage or malformaiton

evidence.dc:description: This variant was identified in 2 brothers with SRS via whole-exome sequencing.

This is the p.P112L variant in SMS, it was identified via perosnal communication in a family and was studied in vitro and in silico in this paper. The functional study has already been awarded points, so this case shouldn't really get additional points given the lack of information.

evidence.rdfs:label: Peng p.P112L family
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Personal communication- could be assumed the patient has SRS
evidence.previousTestingDescription: There was not any information provided other than the fact that this variant was identified in a family via personal communication.

evidence.dc:description: Functionally assessed patient spermine synthase and found that the activity was significantly reduced in the affected males but not in the mother who was a variant carrier.

The phenotype of the individual was not reported beyond moderate-severe ID based on the presence in the cohort. They report that SRS is associated with the variant in HGMD, but this is not directly implicating that the patient had SRS...therefore this case cannot be scored.

evidence.rdfs:label: UK10K_FINDWGA5410846
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted next-gen sequencing of 565 known or candidate ID-associated genes
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: intellectual disability, no further phenotyping conducted
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Individual was part of  a cohort of 986 individuals with moderate to severe ID. Patients were screened for variants in 565 known or candidate ID-associated genes using targeted next-gen seq.

evidence.dc:description: This variant was identified in a patient diagnosed with SRS from the Greenwood Genetic Center, but there was no further phenotypic information or genetic testing info. Also, the functional study was already awarded points so this variant doesn't really need to be scored in this case given the lack of case info.

evidence.rdfs:label: Greenwood Genetic Center
evidence.detectionMethod: There was no sequencing information provided
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Variant was identified in a patient at the Greenwood Genetic Center who was diagnosed with Snyder Robinson.

evidence.dc:description: Functional/computational evidence as well as segregation evidence support that this missense has an impact.

the enzyme activity in the patients including the proband was not detected and there was a notable reduction of spermine and a striking increase in the spermidine spermine ratio. This variant also segregated in 5 obligate female carriers and 2 other affected males

This exon is out of frame, and the RT-PCR data shows that it is missing in patients with the disease. It is exon 4/11 and the variant is absent from gnomAD. It segregated in 5 other males with Snyder-Robinson in this family

This variant was identified in a male patient where the variant was not identified after screening of the mother. The family has no history of symptoms, and the patient's bone phenotype matches up with SRS.

evidence.rdfs:label: C942
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Snyder-Robinson syndrome: generalized tonic-clonic seizures, epileptic encephalopathy , developmental delay, scoliosis, severe osteoporosis
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Relatives did not have symptoms and this was reported as a de novo variant. There were 212 variants reported on target

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded because mother carries the variant unaffected but there is X-inactivation so it fits as a de novo occurance in the mother, passed to the children.
The spermine synthase protein is ubiquitous which explains its widespread impact in disease, but no further points should be given to expression studies because it isn't a specific tissue.
The CAG-SMS mice have widespread overexpression of spermine synthase protein in many organs including the brain.
evidence.rdfs:label: CAG-SMS

evidence.dc:description: Crystal structure supports findings of high levels of spermidine in patients
Since spermidine has been found to be elevated in patients with Snyder Robinson and variants in SMS, this is evidence showing that this is the biochemical function of this enzyme.
evidence.rdfs:label: Crystal structure of SMS

evidence.dc:description: Spermine deficiency is the marker of Snyder Robinson syndrome. The enzyme's ability to convert spermidine to sperimine is highly contingent on the structural integrity of the dimer among other factors. The variants tested here, and the proof of the enzyme's function support that variation in this protein is involved in the spermine deficiency seen in humans with SRS
evidence.rdfs:label: Spermidine to Sperimine catalysis assays

evidence.dc:description: This study showed that several different variants, at 3 different sites can impact the dimerization of the protein. Therein impacting protein function. Some of them were clinically observed variants in patients with SRS.

computational predictions showing impacts on the pKa's and hydrogen bond networks of the crystal structure of the protein as well as entropy effects led to the testing of several different substitutions at the 3 residues tested. using western blots to identify stabilized dimers, they iedntified that the G56S (clinically observed) was predicted to destabilize the dimer but did notinstead lowered dimer affinity...other p.G56 variants destabilized the dimer, however. The p.V132 site served almost as a positive control, because it did not alter dimer stabilization even with several substitutions. The p.I150 site was found to be highly susceptible to dimer destabilization
evidence.rdfs:label: HEK Cell SMS site-directed mutagenesis

evidence.dc:description: Gave default score for characterization of 5 variants.

Western blots showed that the stability of the monomers was compromised by the variants and that there was recduced levels of spermine synthase protein for all the patients either by native or denatured western blot analysis. They also showed that the G56S, F58L, G67E, and P112L variants decreased dimer affinity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Western Blots of 5 different SRS patient variants

evidence.dc:description: Selected the default, this paper showed that the Y328C variant and the p.89I_ins21X variant from the original SRS family had impacts on the protein and that the Y328C vairant had a different mechanism of impact  which may explain its less severe phenotype in the family from this paper.
Western blot analysis, monomer/dimer analysis
evidence.rdfs:label: SPM activity assay

evidence.dc:description: This mouse has already been scored, but the added study showing that the dcAdoMet levels being impacted in mice as well as humans is additional support for the model since this is also seen in patients with SRS. However, it doesn't further connect the phenotypes of the patients that are seen, so it should not add extra points to the model

This mouse has already been scored, but the added study showing that the dcAdoMet levels being impacted in mice as well as humans is additional support for the model since this is also seen in patients with SRS. However, it doesn't further connect the phenotypes of the patients that are seen, so it should not add extra points to the model
evidence.rdfs:label: Gy mice- dcAdoMet

evidence.dc:description: Since this is a fly model and ID was not assessed, it was downgraded. There is good evidence showing the neurodegeneration via immunolabeling and other enzymatic assays, but these enzymatic assays should be counted towards the similarity between humans and the flies.

The model recapitulates the pathological polyamine imbalance of SRS and causes survival defects and synaptic degeneration. The model also provides underlying mechanisms of the pathology of Snyder-Robinson.
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila SMS KO model

evidence.dc:description: There are overlapping features of the mice i.e. the bone phenotype and the neurological symptoms that make it a decent model of the SMS phenotype. Additionally, they do a rescue via breeding with a mouse with transgenic CAG-SMS that rescues all the phenotypes except the bone phenotype. This was downgraded, however, because it seems the deletion is not entirely specific to SMS. NOTE: The other genee involved in the deletion is Phex which is also referred to as PEX, and is expected to be an important factor in poor bone development of Gy mice.

There are some overlapping features in the mice and humans, however this complete knockout in the mice causes there to be no spermine at all. Additionally, this mouse seems to have a deletion that may encompass genes other than just the SMS gene. It is not an ideal model for SRS and the authors state that. NOTE: The other genee involved in the deletion is Phex which is also referred to as PEX, and is expected to be an important factor in poor bone development of Gy mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Gy mouse
